Question_1.Context: The study focuses on the synthesis of metal nanoparticles using Bacillus biocontrol agents.
Question_1.Question: What is the key advantage of using endospore-forming Bacillus biocontrol agents in the production of nano-microbicides?
Question_1.A: They can produce multifarious secondary metabolites.
Question_1.B: They can easily form endospores at the stationary phase.
Question_1.C: They are resistant to heating and dryness.
Question_1.D: They can tolerate Ag+ and Ag nanoparticles.
Question_1.Source: Bacillus cells at the stationary phase form endospores and tolerate Ag+ and Ag nanoparticles (AgNPs), while the cell-free culture supernatant (CFCS) mediates the synthesis of AgNPs.

Question_2.Context: The study discusses the characteristics of silver nanoparticles produced from Bacillus culture and CFCS.
Question_2.Question: What physical characteristic do AgNP–CFCS and AgNP-culture share?
Question_2.A: They have a different color in liquid media.
Question_2.Source: AgNP–CFCS and AgNP-culture have shown similar particle size and morphology, crystalline structures, surface–plasmon–resonance peaks, zeta potential, chemical element compositions, and organic groups.

Question_3.Context: The study evaluates the antibacterial activities of different substances against Pseudomonas syringae pv. actinidiae.
Question_3.Question: Which substance showed the most significant inhibition on the growth of Psa strains ML2-12 and T6-1?
Question_3.Source: AgNP-culture showed the most significant inhibition on the Psa growth.

Question_4.Context: The study investigates the anti-biofilm activities of AgNP–CFCS and AgNP-culture against Psa.
Question_4.Question: What was the outcome of the crystal violet staining of biofilms?
Question_4.A: Psa under AgNP-culture formed the most biofilm.
Question_4.B: Psa under AgNP–CFCS formed the least biofilm.
Question_4.C: Psa under both treatments formed similar amounts of biofilm.
Question_4.D: Psa under the control condition formed the least biofilm.
Question_4.Source: Crystal violet staining and colorimetric assay showed that Psa under AgNP-culture (0.01 mM) and AgNP–CFCS (0.01 mM) formed only 17‒24% biofilm.

Question_5.Context: The study assesses the protective effect of CFCS and AgNPs on kiwifruit leaves from Psa infection.
Question_5.Question: How did the 200-time diluted bio-microbicide and nano-microbicide products affect the lesion area on kiwifruit leaves?
Question_5.B: They had no effect on the lesion area.
Question_5.C: They slightly reduced the lesion area.
Question_5.D: They dramatically reduced the lesion area.
Question_5.Source: The 200-time diluted bio-microbicide and nano-microbicide products dramatically reduced the lesion area to 5% of the leaf area.

Question_6.Context: The study explores the synthesis of AgNPs using a modified nutrient broth.
Question_6.Question: What modification was made to the nutrient broth for the production of CFCS mediating the synthesis of AgNPs?
Question_6.B: Added NaCl to avoid precipitation of Ag+.
Question_6.C: Replaced glucose with sucrose to increase exopolysaccharide production.
Question_6.Source: NaCl was removed to avoid precipitating Ag+. Sucrose 10 g instead of glucose 2.5 g per liter was used to increase the production of exopolysaccharides.

Question_7.Context: The study discusses the potential risks associated with using small-size AgNPs and non-transformed Ag+.
Question_7.Question: What is a solution proposed to reduce the toxic risk of using the synergistic bio-microbicide and nano-microbicide?
Question_7.A: Increasing the size of the AgNP product.
Question_7.B: Using a higher concentration of Ag+.
Question_7.C: Adding more toxic substances to counteract the AgNPs.
Question_7.D: Reducing the transformation rate of Ag+ to Ag0.
Question_7.Source: Increasing the size of the AgNP product > 20 nm in diameter and the transformation rate of Ag+ to Ag0 is a solution to reduce the toxic risk of using the synergistic bio-microbicide and nano-microbicide.

Question_8.Context: The study emphasizes the importance of using biologically benign materials in the production of nano-microbicides.
Question_8.Question: Which materials are suggested as alternatives to reduce regulatory scrutiny?
Question_8.A: Endospore-forming biocontrol agents and Zn-based nanomaterials.
Question_8.Source: Alternatively, the strategy of the coproduction and cooperation of bio-microbicide and nano-microbicide can be realized by using biologically benign and generally recognized as safe (GRAS) materials, such as endospore-forming biocontrol agents belonging to the Bacillus subtilis clade and the Paenibacillus polymyxa complex and Zn-based nanomaterials.

Question_9.Context: The study highlights the challenges in the application of nanotechnology-enabled sustainable agriculture.
Question_9.Question: What are the three major barriers that need to be overcome for the realization of nanotechnology-enabled sustainable agriculture?
Question_9.A: Lack of funding, limited research interest, and technological constraints.
Question_9.B: Scale up production and delivery at field scale, regulatory and safety concerns, and consumer acceptance.
Question_9.C: Climate change, soil degradation, and water scarcity.
Question_9.D: Insect infestations, plant diseases, and crop failures.
Question_9.Source: To realize the full potential of nanotechnology-enabled sustainable agriculture, such as using nanopesticides of metallic nanoparticles in plant protection, three major barriers need to be overcome: scale up production and delivery at field scale, regulatory and safety concerns, and consumer acceptance.

Question_10.Context: The study discusses the challenges associated with the cytotoxic and genotoxic potential of Ag+ and AgNPs.
Question_10.Question: What is suggested as a way to reduce the toxic risk of using the synergistic bio-microbicide and nano-microbicide?
Question_10.B: Using more toxic substances in the formulation.
Question_10.D: Reducing the working concentration of AgNPs and Ag+.
Question_10.Source: The synergistic action of the bio-microbicide and nano-microbicide can reduce the working concentration of AgNPs and Ag+.
